The resource consumption is caused by the non-finality so there's a chicken and egg scenario here.  And a fix exists and will come out in a new release shortly as I understand it.  Users can also switch to other clients which aren't experiencing the issue.

author: yorickdowne
content:
So, "a fix exists", true for some but not all resource consumption issues. Exiting a validator / placing it into exit queue turns out to be quite expensive, and that's causing validators to miss attestations. That's going to be the focus of the Prysm team this week, terence said. Which is great news indeed, I'm glad they could pinpoint the issue so quickly and on a Sunday no less.
They usually release on Monday, so if that cadence holds, then the "regular resource issue" would get fixed with beta.1 tomorrow-esque, and the exit resource issue Nov 9th. And then users need to to update their clients, or enough large wallets need to in order to make a difference.

author: yorickdowne
content: In the meantime exits keep draining inactive eth out. 50k a day maybe between penalty and the 900 validators/day exit queue processing? That was going to be two days to finality, and we're short another 200k-ish because of these resources issues, so --- call it a week? Depending on how the client does and how quickly large wallets can do a mid-cycle upgrade, maybe earlier.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**svantemand**
The point of agreeing on a deadline for mainnet launch (as well as a list of must-haves) is not to predict when mainnet will launch. Rather, it's three fold:

- Helps define scope of remaining tasks. "Stabilize code" can mean anything and a timeline informs the level we agree on.
- Initiates discussions when things take longer than expected. If we are halfway to the deadline and we are far from halfway done with the required work, we need to talk about what is important and what is not. A feature or refactoring of something can easily go from must-have to nice-to-have if it turns out it take 4 or 5 times as long to complete as expected. We need to talk about these things.
- Limit scope to what is actually important. It's far too easy to say "Yeah, let's just start this new nice-to-have feature X, because the people over at Client XYZ will delay the launch anyway", which turns into "We can't launch now, because our feature X is not finished yet!" - repeat ad nauseum.

And finally, we need to stop thinking that delaying Eth2 is free. It has a real cost of dapps not being able to scale, community growing tired and leaving, and competitors peeling off valuable talent from the Ethereum ecosystem. We need all these things to keep momentum and the critical mass of talent that is the basis of Ethereums success! 

If Ethereum 2 delays long enough to devolve into "just another Smart Contract platform struggling to get critical mass", we could easily see 3-4 years more of blockchain drought, with not much actual real-world value to show for it. Ensuring a successful launch of Eth2 is important, but this is what we are up against. And "developers should not give deadlines" is too cheap and easy an answer to lead us anywhere but on the road to failure.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**svantemand**
And yes, the distributed nature of Eth2 does that we can't really have internal deadlines. They will leak out and people will blame us when we change them. The answer is not to stop having deadlines. It's to communicate clearly that they are targets to guide our cooperation, not promises to stake holders or the wider community.
